title: Chinese Embassy donated anti-epidemic materials to Peruvian Ministry of Health in May 2021
description: On May 25, 2021, the Chinese Embassy donated anti-epidemic materials to the Peruvian Ministry of Health. The materials included 170 oxygen concentrators and 1,200 pulse oximeters. The purpose of this donation is to support Peru’s COVID-19 response efforts. The monetary value of this donation is Sol 833,390.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Embassy donated anti-epidemic materials to Peruvian Ministry of Health in May 2021

# Description
On May 25, 2021, the Chinese Embassy donated anti-epidemic materials to the Peruvian Ministry of Health. The materials included 170 oxygen concentrators and 1,200 pulse oximeters. The purpose of this donation is to support Peru’s COVID-19 response efforts. The monetary value of this donation is Sol 833,390.
justification: Project is a healthcare donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of medical equipment for COVID-19 response, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese Embassy donates anti-epidemic materials to Peruvian Ministry of Health in February 2021
description: On February 12, 2021, the Chinese Embassy donated anti-epidemic materials to the Peruvian Ministry of Health. The materials included oxygen concentrators and portable pulse oximeters. This donation was made to support Peru’s COVID-19 response efforts. The estimated monetary value of this donation is Sol $1,685,419.6.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Embassy donates anti-epidemic materials to Peruvian Ministry of Health in February 2021

# Description
On February 12, 2021, the Chinese Embassy donated anti-epidemic materials to the Peruvian Ministry of Health. The materials included oxygen concentrators and portable pulse oximeters. This donation was made to support Peru’s COVID-19 response efforts. The estimated monetary value of this donation is Sol $1,685,419.6.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare support with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of medical equipment (oxygen concentrators and pulse oximeters) for COVID-19 response

title: Chinese Embassy provides USD $414,00 training program to Peru in 2021
description: In 2021, the Chinese Embassy implemented a training program in Peru and executed USD $414,000 for the program. This program included 40 seminars and training provided by Chinese health professionals to 220 Peruvian professionals from Lima, Piura, La Libertad, Ancash, Huánuco, Cajamarca, Junín, Lambayeque, and Arequipa. The seminars focused on health, poverty alleviation, and financial cooperation. The topics of the seminars were on health, poverty alleviation, financial cooperation, tourism management, 5G development, trade, intellectual property, water resources, capacities for NGDOs, development of China, aquaculture green, public administration, clean energy, governance, quarantine of agricultural products, culture, management monetary, trade promotion, foreign assistance, and disaster reduction, among others.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER MULTISECTOR

# Title
Chinese Embassy provides USD $414,00 training program to Peru in 2021

# Description
In 2021, the Chinese Embassy implemented a training program in Peru and executed USD $414,000 for the program. This program included 40 seminars and training provided by Chinese health professionals to 220 Peruvian professionals from Lima, Piura, La Libertad, Ancash, Huánuco, Cajamarca, Junín, Lambayeque, and Arequipa. The seminars focused on health, poverty alleviation, and financial cooperation. The topics of the seminars were on health, poverty alleviation, financial cooperation, tourism management, 5G development, trade, intellectual property, water resources, capacities for NGDOs, development of China, aquaculture green, public administration, clean energy, governance, quarantine of agricultural products, culture, management monetary, trade promotion, foreign assistance, and disaster reduction, among others.
justification: Training program focused on various social and economic development topics without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Training program covering health, poverty alleviation, financial cooperation, and other social development topics

title: Guangdong Provincial Government commits to donating 50,000 surgical masks worth USD $15,290.00 to the Municipality of Lima in September 2021
description: On September 3, 2021, the Guangdong Provincial Government exchanged letters with the Metropolitan Municipality of Lima to express the commitment of donating 50,000 surgical masks to the municipality. The monetary value of this donation is USD $15,290.00. The official confirmation of this donation has yet to be made.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Guangdong Provincial Government commits to donating 50,000 surgical masks worth USD $15,290.00 to the Municipality of Lima in September 2021

# Description
On September 3, 2021, the Guangdong Provincial Government exchanged letters with the Metropolitan Municipality of Lima to express the commitment of donating 50,000 surgical masks to the municipality. The monetary value of this donation is USD $15,290.00. The official confirmation of this donation has yet to be made.
justification: Project is a healthcare-related donation without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of surgical masks, healthcare sector project

title: Chinese Embassy provides Sol $16,357 to Jesús María District Municipality of Peru for ambulance acquisition in October 2021
description: On October 26, 2021, the Chinese Embassy provided Sol $16,357 to Jesús María District Municipality of Peru. The purpose of this donation is to support the municipality’s acquisition of ambulance equipment from the Citizen Security Management.

title: China Eximbank provides $257.9 million preferential buyer’s credit for Phase 1 of Safe City Project
description: On October 20, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Philippines signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on financing cooperation. Then, on January 26, 2018, the Government of Philippines’ National Economic and Development Authority (NEDA) Investment Coordination Committee (ICC) approved Phase 1 of the Safe City Project. The Government of the Philippines submitted an application to China Eximbank  for a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) worth $337,287,207.15 on July 23, 2019. At that time, Government of the Philippines envisaged that the geographical scope of Phase 1 of the Safe City Project would include 18 local government units (LGUs). Then, on July 16, 2019, the ICC-Technical Board noted the compliance status of the Philippines' Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG) with the conditions of the NEDA Board and instructed DILG to submit the following to facilitate the processing of the project loan from China Eximbank: (1) documentation on the approval by the National Telecommunication Commission (NTC) of DILG's frequency spectrum bandwidth application, and information on the corresponding cost requirement for the same; (2) signed Memoranda of Agreement (MOAs) with the participating LGUs; and (3) information and updates on the DILG's efforts to ensure the interconnectivity of the project with all transportation projects with security features. The ICC-Cabinet Committee (ICC-CC) instructed DILG on March 6, 2020 to proceed with the project with the LGUs that had signed MOAs (as project beneficiaries).   On August 26, 2020, NEDA issued a Certification to DILG indicating the Department's compliance with the abovementioned conditions of the ICC and NEDA Board for the approval and confirmation of the project. The Certification likewise covers DILG's compliance with the instruction to prove information on the measures to address project risks such as the approval by NTC of DILG's frequency spectrum bandwidth application, following the DILG's submission of a copy of the permit issued by NTC on said application. Nevertheless, DILG decided to proceed with the implementation of the project with the 16 LGUs with signed MOAs as project beneficiaries, as instructed by the ICC-CC. Then, on June 17, 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of the Philippines signed a $275,942,177 PBC agreement [No.PBC20210080513] for Phase 1 of the Safe City Project. The borrowing terms of the PBC are as follows: a 20-year maturity period, a 7-year grace period, an interest rate of 2%, a default (penalty) interest rate of 0%, a 0.3% commitment fee, and a 0.3% management fee ($827,826.53). The proceeds of the PBC are to be used by the borrower to partially finance a $396,808,479 commercial contract between DILG and the China International Telecommunication Construction Corporation, which was signed on November 19, 2018. Under the terms of the PBC agreement, the borrower can also request that the lender increase the face value of the PBC by $61,345.030.15 (to $337,287,207.15) if it decides to expand the scope of the project (from 16 LGUs to 18 LGUs in order to include Davao City and Makati City as project beneficiaries). Any such modification would need to be codified in a supplemental agreement to the PBC agreement [No.PBC20210080513].   The purpose of this project is to utilize high-definition and advanced closed-circuit television (CCTV cameras) to curb crime and improve emergency response time. According to the DILG, the project will enable more efficient management of public order, safety, and security. Around 12,000 cameras will be installed, with 234 of them installed in Marikina. These cameras will be strategically located in areas where crime, traffic, floods, and fires are prevalent. Through the project, an integrated or converged Intelligent Command, Control, and Communication Center (IC4) will be constructed, in a bid to link the National 911 Public Safety Answering Point, the DILG, the Philippine National Police, the Bureau of Fire Protection, and Bureau of Jail Management and Penology. City-level command centers will also be established.    The first phase of the project will also utilize advanced information and communication technology that will involve video monitoring, multimedia critical communication, information management (big data analytics), and command center systems. Upon completion, the project is expected to reduce the crime rate by 15% and increase the response rate of law enforcement officials and first responders by 25%. These include police and fire personnel that act during natural and human-induced emergencies.   China International Telecommunication Construction Corporation is the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. is also involved in the project as an equipment supplier.  A formal project commencement ceremony took place on November 22, 2019. However, the project is a source of local debate and controversy in the Philippines and efforts were made to prevent the project from ever entering implementation. In January 2018, Senate President Pro Tempore Ralph Recto filed a resolution to probe the project, citing hacking and espionage allegations against Huawei, the project’s equipment supplier. Then, in January 2019, Recto said one provision in the unprogrammed fund section of the 2019 budget bill would disallow the use of funds for “any project intended for public video surveillance and communication system with suppliers or service providers that are considered serious risks to national security or interest or are involved in cases regarding information leakage, computer or network hacking, and other forms of cyberespionage, whether in the Philippines or in other countries.” Another provision lists the foreign-assisted projects that could draw from authorized appropriations for 2019, and the Safe City (or Safe Philippines) project was not among them. On November 22, 2019 Interior Secretary Eduardo Año gave assurances the project will be handled by Filipinos. He said that “they provide the equipment, and after providing the equipment, we’ll take care of this. There will be no adviser, there will be no Chinese technician, all Filipino." In May 2022, DILG Undersecretary Epimaco Densing III announced that the project had been halted indefinitely due to lack of access to funds.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as Phase 1 of the Safe Philippines Project. 2. The China Eximbank loan agreement can be accessed in its entirety via https://www.dropbox.com/s/689gbbwlanfvubw/China%20Eximbank%20PBC%20Agreement%20for%20Phase%201%20of%20Safe%20Philippines%20Project.pdf?dl=03. It is unclear if the China Eximbank loan agreement was suspended or cancelled after the project was 'halted.' As such, for the time being, AidData has status coded Project ID#63248 as in 'Implementation' (rather than 'Suspended' or 'Cancelled'). However, this issue warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Eximbank provides $257.9 million preferential buyer’s credit for Phase 1 of Safe City Project

# Description
On October 20, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Philippines signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on financing cooperation. Then, on January 26, 2018, the Government of Philippines’ National Economic and Development Authority (NEDA) Investment Coordination Committee (ICC) approved Phase 1 of the Safe City Project. The Government of the Philippines submitted an application to China Eximbank  for a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) worth $337,287,207.15 on July 23, 2019. At that time, Government of the Philippines envisaged that the geographical scope of Phase 1 of the Safe City Project would include 18 local government units (LGUs). Then, on July 16, 2019, the ICC-Technical Board noted the compliance status of the Philippines' Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG) with the conditions of the NEDA Board and instructed DILG to submit the following to facilitate the processing of the project loan from China Eximbank: (1) documentation on the approval by the National Telecommunication Commission (NTC) of DILG's frequency spectrum bandwidth application, and information on the corresponding cost requirement for the same; (2) signed Memoranda of Agreement (MOAs) with the participating LGUs; and (3) information and updates on the DILG's efforts to ensure the interconnectivity of the project with all transportation projects with security features. The ICC-Cabinet Committee (ICC-CC) instructed DILG on March 6, 2020 to proceed with the project with the LGUs that had signed MOAs (as project beneficiaries).   On August 26, 2020, NEDA issued a Certification to DILG indicating the Department's compliance with the abovementioned conditions of the ICC and NEDA Board for the approval and confirmation of the project. The Certification likewise covers DILG's compliance with the instruction to prove information on the measures to address project risks such as the approval by NTC of DILG's frequency spectrum bandwidth application, following the DILG's submission of a copy of the permit issued by NTC on said application. Nevertheless, DILG decided to proceed with the implementation of the project with the 16 LGUs with signed MOAs as project beneficiaries, as instructed by the ICC-CC. Then, on June 17, 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of the Philippines signed a $275,942,177 PBC agreement [No.PBC20210080513] for Phase 1 of the Safe City Project. The borrowing terms of the PBC are as follows: a 20-year maturity period, a 7-year grace period, an interest rate of 2%, a default (penalty) interest rate of 0%, a 0.3% commitment fee, and a 0.3% management fee ($827,826.53). The proceeds of the PBC are to be used by the borrower to partially finance a $396,808,479 commercial contract between DILG and the China International Telecommunication Construction Corporation, which was signed on November 19, 2018. Under the terms of the PBC agreement, the borrower can also request that the lender increase the face value of the PBC by $61,345.030.15 (to $337,287,207.15) if it decides to expand the scope of the project (from 16 LGUs to 18 LGUs in order to include Davao City and Makati City as project beneficiaries). Any such modification would need to be codified in a supplemental agreement to the PBC agreement [No.PBC20210080513].   The purpose of this project is to utilize high-definition and advanced closed-circuit television (CCTV cameras) to curb crime and improve emergency response time. According to the DILG, the project will enable more efficient management of public order, safety, and security. Around 12,000 cameras will be installed, with 234 of them installed in Marikina. These cameras will be strategically located in areas where crime, traffic, floods, and fires are prevalent. Through the project, an integrated or converged Intelligent Command, Control, and Communication Center (IC4) will be constructed, in a bid to link the National 911 Public Safety Answering Point, the DILG, the Philippine National Police, the Bureau of Fire Protection, and Bureau of Jail Management and Penology. City-level command centers will also be established.    The first phase of the project will also utilize advanced information and communication technology that will involve video monitoring, multimedia critical communication, information management (big data analytics), and command center systems. Upon completion, the project is expected to reduce the crime rate by 15% and increase the response rate of law enforcement officials and first responders by 25%. These include police and fire personnel that act during natural and human-induced emergencies.   China International Telecommunication Construction Corporation is the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. is also involved in the project as an equipment supplier.  A formal project commencement ceremony took place on November 22, 2019. However, the project is a source of local debate and controversy in the Philippines and efforts were made to prevent the project from ever entering implementation. In January 2018, Senate President Pro Tempore Ralph Recto filed a resolution to probe the project, citing hacking and espionage allegations against Huawei, the project’s equipment supplier. Then, in January 2019, Recto said one provision in the unprogrammed fund section of the 2019 budget bill would disallow the use of funds for “any project intended for public video surveillance and communication system with suppliers or service providers that are considered serious risks to national security or interest or are involved in cases regarding information leakage, computer or network hacking, and other forms of cyberespionage, whether in the Philippines or in other countries.” Another provision lists the foreign-assisted projects that could draw from authorized appropriations for 2019, and the Safe City (or Safe Philippines) project was not among them. On November 22, 2019 Interior Secretary Eduardo Año gave assurances the project will be handled by Filipinos. He said that “they provide the equipment, and after providing the equipment, we’ll take care of this. There will be no adviser, there will be no Chinese technician, all Filipino." In May 2022, DILG Undersecretary Epimaco Densing III announced that the project had been halted indefinitely due to lack of access to funds.
justification: The project focuses on public safety and security through CCTV cameras and command centers, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Installation of 12,000 CCTV cameras, construction of Intelligent Command Center, focus on crime reduction and emergency response improvement

title: Bank of China provides $100 million loan to Globe Telecom to finance its capital expenditures
description: On May 14, 2021, Globe Telecom, Inc. signed a $100 million term loan facility with Bank of China (Hong Kong) Limited. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance its capital expenditures.
staff_comments: 1. Globe Telecom, Inc., commonly known as ‘Globe’, is a major provider of telecommunications services in the Philippines. The company operates the largest mobile network in the Philippines and one of the largest fixed-line and broadband networks. As of December 2022, Globe's total mobile subscriber base reached 87.9 million. It is also the country's largest telecommunications company in terms of market capitalization. The company's principal shareholders are Ayala Corporation and Singtel. It is listed on the Philippine Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol GLO and had a market capitalization of PHP 363 billion as of the end of August 2021.
combined_text:
# Sector
BUSINESS AND OTHER SERVICES

# Title
Bank of China provides $100 million loan to Globe Telecom to finance its capital expenditures

# Description
On May 14, 2021, Globe Telecom, Inc. signed a $100 million term loan facility with Bank of China (Hong Kong) Limited. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance its capital expenditures.
justification: Loan facility for general capital expenditures without specific environmental or energy transition focus
evidence: General loan for capital expenditures, no specific project details provided

title: Chinese Government donates 600,000 Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $10.8 million in February 2021
description: In 2021, the Chinese Government donated approximately 5 million doses of Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of the Philippines. The Chinese Government delivered 600,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of the Philippines on February 28, 2021. At least 100,000 of these doses were donated by the People's Liberation Army (PLA) of China to the Armed Forces of the Philippines. The shipment arrived at the Vilamo Military Airport in Manila. A handover ceremony was held with Philippine President Duterte and the Chinese Ambassador to the Philippines, Huang Xilian, among others, in attendance.   Then, on March 24, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 400,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of the Philippines. On August 20, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 739,200 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of the Philippines. One day later, on August 21, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 260,800 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of the Philippines. Then, on October 24, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 1 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of the Philippines. Then, on December 14, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 2 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of the Philippines.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinopharm/Sinovac COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the February 2021 donation as $10.8 million.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates 600,000 Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $10.8 million in February 2021

# Description
In 2021, the Chinese Government donated approximately 5 million doses of Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of the Philippines. The Chinese Government delivered 600,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of the Philippines on February 28, 2021. At least 100,000 of these doses were donated by the People's Liberation Army (PLA) of China to the Armed Forces of the Philippines. The shipment arrived at the Vilamo Military Airport in Manila. A handover ceremony was held with Philippine President Duterte and the Chinese Ambassador to the Philippines, Huang Xilian, among others, in attendance.   Then, on March 24, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 400,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of the Philippines. On August 20, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 739,200 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of the Philippines. One day later, on August 21, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 260,800 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of the Philippines. Then, on October 24, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 1 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of the Philippines. Then, on December 14, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 2 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of the Philippines.
justification: Project involves donation of vaccines for public health purposes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of Sinovac and Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Philippines for public health purposes

title: Chinese Government provides 600 tons of rice to Visaya Disaster Response Center of the Philippine Department of Social Welfare and Development in October 2021
description: On October 21, 2021, the Chinese Government provided 600 tons of rice to the Visaya Disaster Response Center of the Philippine Department of Social Welfare and Development. Chinese Consul General Jia Li handed over the rice to the department on behalf of the Chinese government. The donation was made to help Philippine citizens affected by COVID-19 and the rice will be included in family food packs which will be distributed during Philippine government response operations. Each bag of rice weighs 50 kilos and is expected to help 100,000 households. The Visaya Disaster Response Center is in charge of distributing the rice.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation. Consul General Jia Li, and directors of the Philippine Seventh District Social Welfare and Development Bureau attended the ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
Chinese Government provides 600 tons of rice to Visaya Disaster Response Center of the Philippine Department of Social Welfare and Development in October 2021

# Description
On October 21, 2021, the Chinese Government provided 600 tons of rice to the Visaya Disaster Response Center of the Philippine Department of Social Welfare and Development. Chinese Consul General Jia Li handed over the rice to the department on behalf of the Chinese government. The donation was made to help Philippine citizens affected by COVID-19 and the rice will be included in family food packs which will be distributed during Philippine government response operations. Each bag of rice weighs 50 kilos and is expected to help 100,000 households. The Visaya Disaster Response Center is in charge of distributing the rice.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation. Consul General Jia Li, and directors of the Philippine Seventh District Social Welfare and Development Bureau attended the ceremony.
justification: Project is focused on humanitarian food aid with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 600 tons of rice provided as food aid, distributed through government social welfare programs, aimed at COVID-19 relief and food security
